pros: Dana-Farber is an incredible place to work. The people, mission, operations, pay, and benefits are only some of the positives. I have spent 10 years in the organization and hope to build my career here like many at the Institute. We are making strides across all cancers and leading the way thanks to strong leadership and brilliant minds within the organization.
cons: N/A - I come to work very happy and motivated every day.

pros: I think the company as a whole and its mission is great!
cons: I had a disappointing experience with the application process for the Research Assistant, Bilingual in Spanish position. While I have always been enthusiastic about contributing to research and working with this company, my experience was negative. After submitting my application on Indeed, it took approximately a month to receive a response for an interview, which I understood and remained excited about. However, during the interview at the Brockton, Massachusetts location, the interviewer displayed extreme rudeness, rushed through my responses, and asked an inappropriate question. Unfortunately, this led me to decide not to proceed and finish the interview. I acknowledge that this isolated incident does not reflect the company as a whole, as I still believe it is a great organization to work for. However, I believe it is important to share my experience to potentially benefit other applicants. Throughout my career, I have undergone numerous interviews and have never encountered anything negative or felt compelled to leave a negative review. However, in this particular case, I felt compelled to share my experience. I am uncertain whether I was a victim of discrimination, if the interviewer was having a difficult day, or what exactly led to this encounter. Regardless, I genuinely wish the company continued success and pray that the research being conducted will make a positive impact.

review_title: Every horror story you've heard about academia is found here
pros:
Good location
As a whole the institute does impactful stuff
cons:
Really cannot imagine a more toxic work environment. Misogynistic managers who only care about boosting their own reputation and their own fragile egos are rampant. They are more than willing to break rules and manipulate their results and do sleazy and lazy work to get that Nature publication. And if you aren't willing to do the same then you're threatened with the "if you want my recommendation for grad/med school" card. The amount of times this was used against me was immense. All of the other research/lab techs I've spoken with since leaving left very shortly as well, and they've since opened up and admitted that their experience was also incredibly toxic. We all struggled to get good LORs even though we were working all the time, including staying until midnight on Fridays and showing up at 8am on Saturdays. All because our managers were on a power trip and felt we needed to "prove" ourselves. The females were treated especially bad and yelled at and reprimanded for no reason, and our hard work blatantly dismissed. For example, when I tried to go above and beyond on an assignment I was told "Okay I'm going to be blunt. You're just an assistant." When I or other females would ask questions, the manager would roll his eyes and dodge it altogether, but would then be quizzed on the spot on what the other people in the meeting had just said. When this was brought to our PI we were told it was going to be addressed only for matters to become worse, so we learned to stay quiet. On top of that when I left, my manager texted me threatening me that if I didn't do xyz (for free, by the way) then I was throwing away my chances at publication and LORs. This was after my last day at work and after having been promised lead co-authorship many months prior. 

Overall terrible experience and sad I was so tunnel-visioned that I didn't realize I deserved better. Have had MUCH better work experiences since leaving, and have heard from others that this is a common experience here but it's very "hush hush."

Many technicians and research assistants are expected to work long hours as if they were PhD students, but with no ownership of projects. (So mind as well get a PhD, if you're thinking science as a career.) Poor compensation, hard to get paid for overtime. HR seems mismanaged, and can expect slow to reply. Also, why did we re-brand? It may seem like an insignificant gripe, but most everyone was upset about the logo change. We liked the red Dana-Farber. It stood out, and the branding made sense. Yet the company spent significant money to switch branding that blends in with all of the other healthcare companies in the area.

pros: Dana Farber is a well known institution and the name holds prestige around the world. The doctors and nurses are busy treating patients and discovering new therapies. Great opportunity for those in the medical fields to shadow oncologists and learn first hand what the cutting edge genomic research can bring and give back to the patients quality of life
cons: As a non-clinician, there is high turnover in researcher and project management positions. We are overworked and under appreciated, with few opportunities to advance our careers and attend research conferences (those are typically reserved for the physicians). There are too many "middle men" to run decisions by and I constantly felt micromanaged by other departments. No one wants to take responsibilities for the decisions necessary to write or run a research protocol, and the researchers are the first to be blamed when something doesnt go right. Many of my coworkers were young, immature, and needed a lot of guidance on how to complete daily office tasks, that often consumed most of my day. The physicians are too busy to complete the paperwork necessary to keep open clinical trials organized and prepared in the event of audits.

cons: I have no cons to tell

pros: great collaborators, environment, interdisciplinary, cutting-edge
cons: HR is a bit archaic and difficult to navigate

pros: Nice work environment and easy to meet great collaborator
cons: High living costs. Little crowded in the context of traffic.

pros: Great team of pharmacists and technicians, supportive environment and rewarding patient population
cons: Can be busy but that is true for every pharmacy, no major cons

job_title: Software Developer in New York, NY
pros: Opportunity to work in a company with excellent conditions
cons: Slightly low salary for those who have no work experience

job_title: Oncology Nurse Practitioner in Boston, MA
pros: If your goal in healthcare is to make an impact in the lives of patients, this is the place. You will be surrounded by smart and caring people across all the domains of healthcare providers, at all levels of experience. There is always the opportunity to learn and to teach, and the Jimmy Fund events are awe-inspiring (I know that sounds hyperbolic, but it’s really true - take part in a Jimmy Fund walk and see for yourself). I am honored to be part of the team at Dana-Farber, and I am just amazed at the quality of work that goes on here.
cons: Caregiver burnout is a very real thing in oncology nursing, and the current push from management to increase productivity makes it a bigger problem. I am afforded a great deal of respect by my patients and their families, but I do not feel that management has a good understanding of what it is I bring to Dana-Farber and the ways I further their mission of providing expert, compassionate care to people with cancer. It’s very disheartening.

pros: Exciting science, supportive lab, lots of room to grow
cons: Longwood medical area congestion during rush hour

pros: Great learning experience, patient care experience, and introduction to clinical trials.
cons: Rigorous job, high burn out rate.

pros: Good research experience for graduate students
cons: Paid less for graduate students

job_title: Research Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Great people, great benefits, great mission
cons: Not much room for growth

pros: I have never worked anywhere where people are so dedicated to the mission of the institute.  Everyone bends over backwards for patients and families to provide a wonderful experience for everyone that visits.  In addition, the faculty are at the cutting edge of research and continue to push the envelope on everything they do.  In addition, the people are for the most part, great.
cons: Lack of communication among departments is the biggest issue.  Everyone is rowing in their own direction without consideration for others.  As a result, some decision end up not making a lot of sense.  HR does not know how to serve it's customers, employees. IT is run by Partners (which runs MGH and BWH and have more of a clinical focus than Dana-Farber) as a result, they are unable to provide any real useful support and help, particularly to research, which is often an afterthought at best.  In addition, I've never worked in an organization this politically charged.  You've got to watch your back becasue there is always someone right behind you ready to stab you in the back.

pros: Great Working community and enviorment!
cons: There were no cons to working at DFCI

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator (Breast Oncology) in Boston, MA
pros: The benefits are fantastic (401K, vision, dental, life insurance...) and the job definitely gives you a lot of experience if you want to go into biotech, pharma, or med school.
cons:
There's a reason most CRCs only last 1-2 years. The management in Breast Oncology is very poor. Both managers don't give a lot of feed back and give people a LOT of work. Unfortunately, they don't give overtime so I know people who have no choice but to work for free. (The patients will suffer otherwise!) They also don't really oversee a lot of what we do, so when you take over someone's job you end up having to clean up someone else's messes. The only time they talk to you is if you're in trouble because you're overworked.

Some research RN's are bullies. The CRCs are often scapegoats for their mistakes. Also, they never get called out for this behavior. 

The MDs never talk to you unless they need to so if you're hoping to get mentorship to go to medschool, don't work here.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros:
The institution invests about half of its margin on research and fosters a supportive research environment.

Each department seems to be given a lot of freedom to operate, and the other departments and executives for the most part stay out of the way (except Information Security).

The pay is comparable or higher compared to other institutions in the Boston area, with a few exceptions.

Some DFCI postdoctoral fellows benefit from being part of the Harvard community with plenty of opportunities of training and career development, as well as access to Harvard facilities (at a small additional fee).

Boston is a vibrant research hub.
cons:
Your personal experience will largely depend on your principal investigator. There are plenty of horrible bosses in this competitive environment -- they are judged based on their ability to acquire research grants and generate scientific output, not on whether they are decent human beings.

Postdoctoral Research Fellows (PhD) actually have the same job title as other "Research Fellows" (BSc, MS) and the same pay and benefits.

Living expenses in Boston are high. The public transit buses are rarely on time and shifts are often cut. Forget about driving.

review_title: Not the best place to work, for sure...
pros: DFCI has a noble mission - to provide treatment for cancer patients as well as research new avenues toward understanding and treating this disease.
cons:
I've experienced a great number of inept, if not malicious, management practices here.  When issues arise, the HR department is the last place to go.  They simply do NOT support the average employee.
Compensation - salaries paid are definitely on the low end of the scale.  Benefits are so-so, they used to offer a variety of health care plans, but now have downgraded to just the Harvard Pilgrim HMO//PPO plan.  They eliminated the Retirement Plan that the Institute used to pay into for Professional Staff.
One more pet-pieve - Dana-Farber does not recognize Patriot's Day as a Holiday, so for all of those employees running or volunteering for the Jimmy Fund in the Boston Marathon - tough luck, you have to use up a vacation day to participate.

review_title: A place of angel and evil
pros: prestigious institute, smart coworkers, exposure to cutting-edge technology and ideas, good location, the institute is committed to advance patient care and research, good facility
cons: Postdoctoral research fellows are treated very badly. The postdoc are not treated well as a whole but DFCI is the worst among three prestigious universities I have been working or studying at. The relationship between faculty and postdoc is like master/apprentice in the dark age. The career of a apprentice is heavily dependent on the master, which gives PI a superior power over postdoc. The consequence is often arrogance, rudeness and misuse of the power on the PI side. One mean PI could ruin a few years of a postdoc's life or even worse totally ruin the scientific career of the postdoc. DFCI did little to protect the group.

review_title: Good place to work if you don't own a car
pros: Dana-Farber does a lot of good work for its patients. Culture is patient-centric.  Patients always come first.
cons: Don't work here if you need to drive in from the suburbs.  They say they have plenty of parking, but forget to mention that the waiting list for parking lots can take years. And cost $$$$. I waited 18 months to get a parking space.  And what do you do in the interim??  All parking lots require lengthy shuttle bus rides, so add that into your commute time.  Brookline Avenue traffic congestion is a nightmare.  All parking in the buildings is reserved for Doctors and Patients.

pros: stable job, it is just a job. that is it. This is not a place to make money or learn something. once you're trained, you have to repeat what you are told millions of times. literally you could work to death here IF you are lucky to survive the lay-off wave. Oh, benefit is just above average.
cons: 8.5 working hour for you. no bonus. 2-3% raise every year. limited space for your career development.

review_title: Good Gap-Year Job for Grad School Applications
pros: Incredibly friendly staff in my department (at all levels), flexible hours (I could start my work day earlier in order to leave sooner), able to work from home some days, great holiday and paid vacation.
cons: A bachelor's degree is strongly preferred but highly unnecessary, in my opinion. Nothing I did required a high level of education. The only people who fill these positions are recent college grads (myself included) who will work for anything, because these jobs are never a long-term gig for us. They serve to boost our grad school applications. I only did this job for a year. Currently getting my MS for a job that  pay me at least double, to start. Shame that this "college" criterion keeps job opportunities away from those who would stay for longer and could benefit a lot from it economically.

review_title: Amazing place for patients, but not for non-clinical employees
pros: Work was inspiring and rewarding. Everyone is working toward the mission, not a big paycheck. Medical/dental/visual insurance was very good. Standard 40-our work week with very little expected on nights/weekends. Clinical staff & researchers all seem to love their jobs and be very satisfied.
cons: No room for growth - it is rare for anyone in their 20s or 30s to stay more than 3 years. No promotions, no market value raises, no opportunities to move up into more senior roles. Very outdated style of management.

pros:
- Great benefits! 401k, comprehensive health care, etc
- They hire talented and hard-working employees that go the extra mile every day
- Managers are receptive, patient, and supportive 
- Compensation is level with other hospitals
cons:
- Employees get pigeonholed into a position
-  Difficult to move from one department to another
- Over the years, management slowly got rid of incentives for employees (preceptor pay for training other employees)
- Patient population continues to grow, but no additional support staff was hired to alleviate extra growth. As a result:
- High turnover rate
- CASS and their managers are overworked

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator II in Boston, MA
pros: The Benefits package is loaded and really covers all walks of life. Ability to take time-off come frequently especially at different times of the year when it is so necessary to take a break. It is a non-profit so it is for a good cause in fighting cancer and has great fundraisers. It is at the pinnacle of healthcare research so there is a lot of passion present everywhere you go. DFCI has an incredible mission statement that from first read makes you proud of the institute.
cons: There are many positions that are only temporary or have a short time requirement as many people have a goal to return to school for further education. This causes little advancement for non-doctoral positions from base level support. It can be a challenging place to work so don't work here if you enjoy slacking!

review_title: Cancer patients will be hard pressed to find a better standard of care. Early career researchers should look elsewhere.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Dana-Farber Cancer Institute has a history of excellence when it comes to patient care and it has some amazing MDs, nurses and admin staff. The level of commitment they have for their patients is truly inspirational. They also seem to enjoy reasonable pay and benefits, but are still below the standards of other nearby facilities.
cons: Research staff are treated with little respect by principal investigators who's interests seem entirely focused on what latest research developments can be patented. There is no support for the career advancement of young research trainees and little or no interest in improving conditions for them within the system. Beyond the occasional (semi-annual) workshop or talk about alternative career paths there is no structure for career transitioning either. Burnout seems prevalent throughout the community.

review_title: Company could do better although nothing can help lab heads do better
pros:
Some departments are better than others. Medical oncology has better benefits and morale than cancer immunology. 

Postdoc office is on top of things such as bringing outside career information into the company.
cons:
Supervisors and staff do not explain anything in much detail, either they are clueless or they are secretive to employees, which is not good.

You are expected to come to work during inclement weather (big snowstorm of the past winter).

Some people in the company may take 2 weeks to respond to your email.

No sense of community or teamwork.

The company doesnt do a good job of providing a good culture or value.  Free ice cream for employees once a year doesnt help.

Seems like everyone in the labs including the lab heads get jobs in the company based on referrals not on qualifications or experience.

pros: If you are full time employee, the benefits are good. You are doing work at an institution that is treating cancer, how much better can you feel about their business? The buildings/working environment are fine, some extremely nice, all at least ok. These is a lot of flexibility in many roles around start/end times for your workday - in back office jobs. Many of your co-workers are smart and you don't have to waste time explaining the obvious.
cons: Many of your co-workers have too high a level of self-regard, treat others with a bit of high-handedness. Salaries are significantly lower than in a profit-driven business. There are many layers of management/administration - some needed, some redundant. Every penny is twice-counted to point where the cost of counting becomes costly. Like any clinical setting it's a bit authoritarian, you are in a regulated environment, not doing creative work at, say Apple.

review_title: Mission is worthwhile but areas like HR are a drag
pros: The Institute has a lot of talented and well intentioned  people that make coming to work worthwhile.  The benefits are great.  If you're in a good area with a supportive manager and interesting work then it's great to be here.
cons: Compensation is low.  They hired someone to lead the compensation department in human resources who was marketed as someone who could solve the low pay that exist all over, but so far as I can see she's done nothing to help resolve the problem except talk your head off.  There are too many unnecessary meetings that take away time from focusing on the important stuff.

review_title: Inspiring coworkers, this hospital will open so many doors for you
pros: The work done here is amazing, every corner of the hospital has the best of the best, smartest, brightest personal... speaking from the academic side.  the hospital finance sector, insurance, billing and accounting is very sub par.  You will find very nice coworkers and a overall happy environment. Excellent benefits, more than half off of healthcare and dental.  They pinched their 401k over the ;past couple of years, but they offer tuition reimbursment.
cons: you cant judge a work place as a whole, especially one this big. i have work in 2 separate departments and got 2 totally different experiences. one very bad, and one very good..... but great thing about this place is once youre in. it's very easy to move to a different job if you don't like the current one your in within the same company.

review_title: A good place to settle in if you have a working spouse
pros: Excellent staff, work that is actually advancing cancer research.  Transportation is easy to and from and the benefits package, while not as good some places (i.e., Whitehead Institute), is relatively fair.  Not a lot of politics and backbiting which makes for a pleasant work day.
cons: too much fundraising and rah-rah, dealing with the administrative personnel at Brigham and Women's hospital can be quite enervating. The HR department is not the best and the personnel do not often seem to have a handle on what is actually required for a position.  Upper management is remote and a little too "big picture".

pros: Highly respectable mission, well-intentioned co-workers, basic benefits, 50% off T-pass, 15 vacation days + 11 national holidays and a few floaters.
cons: No maternity leave which I find surprising from a healthcare organization that is very compassionate and caring towards their patients. Not only do you not get any paid time off, but you have to use all your vacation time, sick time, etc during your "12 weeks" and back pay for health insurance when you come back. They encourage staff to go above and beyond for patients which is super, but why not extend the same set of  values to their employees?

review_title: A great place to work if you are looking to go into medicine.
pros: If you're seeking to go into the medical field this is a very good place to work.  There are many opportunities to shadow people and learn more about the field you are interested in.  It is one of the best cancer facilities in the nation.  It focuses on research advances to better treat patients.   They have extremely good benefits and really respect all employees.  They are supportive of their employees pursuing and having a well balanced healthy life.  They are good about finding the best fit for you if you are unhappy with your current position.
cons: The pay is less than at private research companies.  It is hard to get promoted within your department.

review_title: Focus is on patients, not research, which is both good and bad
job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: The company clearly cares about its patients, as most of their resources are directed at these departments.
cons: Since almost all of the resources are patient-directed, there is little left for research. Being an afterthought of the company definitely wears on you mentally, especially when post-docs are working 70-80 hours a week. I think this disparity in how funds and resources are allocated does affect the overall culture at DFCI.

review_title: If you're looking for colleagues who are honest and respectful, look elsewhere
pros:
Compensation and benefits are good, but think 'golden handcuffs'.

From a humanities perspective, wonderfully rewarding to help those with cancer.
cons:
Strongly academic environment, therefore, sadly, very high levels of narcissistic personality types.
Mega-egomaniacs.
If you are not a lead MD there, NO ONE has your back. 
I have never witnessed more manipulation, lying and game-playing around me in a work place.
Human resources not helpful in this regard.
It's all about the lead MD's there and the $$$ they bring in.
If they are acting inappropriately, NO ONE cares.  Blind eyes are turned to keep these folks there.
The turnover is high for anyone below them.

review_title: Great place to work with a great mission and good opportunities
pros: Every department is different but I certainly lucked out. In every department the majority of people take pride in where they work knowing it is a first class cancer treatment center. Many of the employees know people who have had treatment and that instills a sense of passion no matter what level of work you are involved in. Since the Institute is so large there are lots of opportunities to grow and develop.
cons: Like any large organization, change is hard to implement. Compensation is also more low to mid-range but the time-off and work hours make-up for it (at least in my case).

job_title: Research Data Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Great place for fostering relationships with professionals, especially if you are someone looking to get into the medical field. Lots of entry-level positions so great opportunity for recent graduates to get experience in the healthcare field.
cons: Job turnover is incredibly high for entry-level positions because employees are easily replaced. Organization  tries to maximize profits at the expense of their employees and quality of care.  Want to hire fewer employees and instead add more responsibilities for current employees, but offers poor compensation and no raises.

review_title: Development/JF is a great place to work if you have no career ambitions
pros: My coworkers were awesome to work with. Benefits were decent, the location was convenient, and Dana-Farber has an excellent reputation and mission.
cons:
Development/JF has an oppressively conservative work culture. Progress moves at a snail's pace, if at all. Employees aren't discouraged from taking initiative, but if you don't have the word "director" in your job title, then your voice will be much softer than others. Leadership and initiative just aren't expected from low level employees.

Dana-Farber's Development department can be a good stepping stone in your career, but you will almost certainly stepping up to a better position elsewhere.

job_title: Lead Research Technician in Boston, MA
pros: I love almost everything about working at DFCI. The people here are truly committed to advancing our knowledge about cancer and related disease, care about the needs of patients, and strive for research excellence. I have worked here for 5 years and have no plans to leave.
cons: I think it's pretty shameful for a medical institute to provide no paid maternity leave. I understand the US doesn't require companies to provide this benefit, but that doesn't make it right. If DFCI truly wants to recruit and maintain top-notch female employees at all levels, it needs to provide us with comprehensive benefits that allow us to balance career with family.

pros: Dana-Farber is a well respected brand and you get the sense that you are working for the best nonprofit in Boston. The research done at DFCI is impressive.
cons: The environment at Dana-Farber is not collaborative. There is a very "leave your personality at the door" feeling and coworkers are discouraged from sharing very much about their personal lives. The environment is also very competitive, so people are not willing to help one another. As with any office, there are some great employees who do not fall into this category but the majority of people and management do.

review_title: Wonderful people focused on a worthwhile cause but very politically charged
pros: I've never worked anywhere in which everyone in the organization is so passionate about the mission (in this case, curing cancer and doing everything possible to make cancer patients' lives easier).  From top to bottom, the organization truly cares.
cons: As with many larger organizations, the bureaucracy and red tape are substantial.  As much as people want to eliminate these issues, there is no commitment from leadership to make the organization function efficiently and effectively together.  As a result, each departments tends to run in their own direction.

pros: Interesting work, strong culture of excellence and very intelligent people. The science that is happening here is amazing. My coworkers are committed and motivated. Development department is successful and professional. Good benefits and pay.
cons: Muddy policies and procedures and a somewhat burdensome hierarchical system of approvals. Micromanaging. People here are reluctant to embrace emergent technologies on the administrative side which could improve processes. Sort of a "this is how we've always done it" perspective.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Working as a research coordinator is a great experience. It's really humbling to work with such well respected doctors and scientists. It gives good insight to how clinical research is conducted and you're able to see things from both the doctor's and pharma's perspectives.
cons: This may not be the best position for someone looking for more direct mentorship and clinic time. The majority of my position was spent in the office, unlike other CRIS coordinators. You will likely work a lot of late hours to meet deadlines. Work culture is also highly group dependent as DFCI separates it's coordinators by disease group (GYN, Head and Neck, Leukemia, Breast, etc.)

pros: very good facilities and environment, location is great, no places to have lunch around except Yawkey canteen, Harvard affiliation is great, exceptional speed and accuracy on recruitment and getting all the paperwork sorted
cons: For a post-doc the pay is sluggish and remains the same independent of tenure, experience and lab-s income, to qualify for some benefits one needs to be employed with DFCI for at least a year, no significant physchological support for the members.

pros: The majority of the people care about the mission an the patients.  There is good entry level opportunity here.  Great work - life balance.  No evenings and minimum weekend work for a select few.  the facilities are amazing and benefits are good.
cons: Salaries are low to start, and hard to catch up once employeed.  With th eincreased work load and small staff, the high performers get great experience but tend to be over worked as the low performers can cruise by.

pros:
good research resources

high level science
cons:
Big disparity of treatment between Postdocs and the rest of employees (e.g. retirement plan, salary)

very low level of interaction/collaboration between labs

Often  PIs are very bad  to manage postdocs. the only  goal often is the high impact  publication

No help on career development for Postdoc

The Postdoc office does a great job trying to help postdoc but they have  limited resource and time

pros: Mission, colleagues.  The physicians, nurses and researchers at this institute impress me everyday.
cons: Upper management lacks direction and focus.  Goals of the institute are not well defined, nor are there performance metrics to determine whether or not they are being met.

review_title: Don't plan to grow here. get in, get experience, get out.
pros: Good place to gain experience
cons: Zero career track or chance for professional recognition. Don't plan to grow here. get in, get experience, get out. Go take your skills to a company that will pay you and value your worth as an employee

job_title: Clinical Administrative Support Specialist in Boston, MA
pros:
Benefits are decent.
There are some excellent doctors there.
cons:
Too much bureaucracy that has caused many employees to leave DFCI.  Upper management gives the impression that they could care less about employees being happy in their job.  Poor communication between management and their employees.  Because of many people leaving the institute, everyone is overworked.
HR acts like they don't care about internal issues.
Some of the doctors are so focused on their "numbers" for research work that they forget about what really matters.
DFCI is unfair to those who take advantage of FMLA, upon your return management gives you more and more work to make up for being out.

pros:
Tons of interesting research going on and opportunities to attend seminars from some of the smartest oncologists in the industry. Depending on what research program/physician you work for, you may have the opportunity to work on some phenomenal research projects.

Good benefits package if you aren't an expecting mother (no paid family leave for non-physician staff which frankly is deplorable coming out of a Harvard Medical School affiliate).
cons:
Maybe it's because of DFCI's affiliation with Harvard Medical School or this is just a general issue across academic medicine, but many of the physicians I worked with were incredibly arrogant. Research Assistants/Administrative Assistants are rarely asked to contribute ideas in meetings and are seen as clerks that push paperwork through the huge bureaucracy of DFCI. Additionally, the workplace culture does not encourage any camaraderie around anything including the work that you do. One of my study teams threw a Christmas party and none of the MDs that worked on the study showed up OR responded to the invitation stating that they wouldn't make it. From my experience, the MDs at DFCI do not care about the staff that work below them and only view them as a means to an end. If you're looking for a workplace where upper-manamgent sees you as something more than a list of job functions I suggest you look beyond Dana-Farber.

Additionally, there is little to no room for growth in entry-level Research Assistant/CRC jobs. The pay is abysmal- especially when compared to the salaries of the higher-ups. I was explicitly told in my interview that I would not be able to advance from my role to a higher role without having a Master's degree. Many, many of my colleagues were told this as well. This attitude makes it so that everyone at DFCI puts an expiration date on their employment. I performed worse and did not feel inspired to go the extra mile because I knew that my extra efforts would not be rewarded with promotions and/or a significant raise. 

Lastly, the management structure is significantly outdated. People do not interact face-to-face on anything other than in meetings, which many physicians blow off, leave early, or are only partially present because they have so many other things going on. Other staff easily excuse the behaviors of the physicians, however I did not find their excuses to be acceptable. People would work remotely and not let their subordinates aware of their absence from the office. My simple questions would go unanswered for weeks to months at times. Then I would get reprimanded for not having the answer to the question that I had posed multiple times. DFCI needs to look to other peer-institutions and more innovative healthcare companies to think about better ways to manage their research support staff.

review_title: Great research resources, administrative support lacking
pros: Compared to other research institutions, it is great to have all necessary cores within one roof. Amazing faculty list leading to infinite collaborations within an arm's reach.
cons: Support from non-research members is lacking to the same degree. Administrative support for issues such as access to networks, user management, finance issues, product ordering are very neglected. Lack of intra-department communication can be issue at times.

review_title: Good place for patients, not for employees
job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Boston, MA
pros: Good benefits, interesting research, location, recognition, Harvard Medical School
cons: Very negative atmosphere. It is as if management aims at discouragement of employees. The common concept of HR was replaced by a 'business mode;' that in the end supports neither employees nor employer but acts as a state within the state supporting only itself. it is not unusual to be told by employees that they will not support a function they were hired for without any consequences when managers were informed about the incident.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Good stepping stone job for recent college grads looking to go to med/nursing/PA school, or to go work in pharma development.
cons: If you're looking to go to PA school, you don't get a lot of patient exposure at DFCI vs other hospitals.  That being said, if you make an effort and go out of your way, you can get patient contact.  I have known multiple CRCs at DFCI who left to go to PA school, and am currently applying myself.

review_title: A great place for New England area cancer patients, a not-so great place for cancer research.
pros: Dana-Farber Cancer Institute has a strong interest in providing great care for patients with cancer and has brilliant minds working on both the clinical and research sides. Staff working directly for the hospital - i.e. administrative staff members, clinical side personnel (nurses, medical techs etc.) seem to enjoy reasonable, albeit not great, pay and benefits.
cons: The medical research side of DFCI seems to suffer from a critical lack of support at the executive level. Lab spaces are old and worn, with most not seeing any sort of updating in 30+ years (think leaky faucets, dirty old bathrooms etc). Research fellows can do extremely well, bringing in their own grants and money and yet DFCI turns around and treats these folks as "contract employees." That is once you enhance the prestige of the hospital by bringing in outside research money, they change your status from "regular employee" to "contract employee" mostly so they can take away all the benefits entitled to regular employees - bit of a perverse reward system.  Like most of Harvard Medical School the research side suffers from dictators running their kingdom anyway they see fit. Attitudes and egos are ridiculous. Research staff are treated horribly by the "principal investigators." Virtually ZERO support for career advancement of young research trainees. If you're a young researcher this is a great place to go and make one or two high impact papers, but then get out QUICK! If you're good, you're seen as future competition - not someone who should be supported and helped with career transition. Again, like much of Harvard Medical School things are extremely political! Incompetent scientists get hired as full time research faculty members if they came from the "right" labs as post-docs, even if they barely know the basics of putting together a simple scientifc experiment.  This may not be unique to DFCI and Harvard, but a problem with academia in general and one that seems to get worse as money gets tighter. Unfortunately, DFCI and Harvard have not led the way in changing this type of nepotism.

pros: Employees work together to provide best possible care for patients.  Great atmosphere and very mission driven.  Internal training opportunities regularly offered.  Fast paced but purposeful. Management acknowledges staff at all levels, organizational respect. CEO is engaged and approachable.  Good benefits.
cons: Work can be stressful due to time sensitivity and fast paced work environment. Officespace is difficult to manage as space can be an issue. Depending on the department, some doctors can be difficult personalities to work with.

pros: I get to work with great physician scientists and be part of new research. DFCI does a lot of service, fundraising, and volunteer programs, so I love being a part of that. As a researcher, I get to go to seminars and lectures held at the hospital which enriches my science education and keeps me up to date on what's happening in the field.
cons: Pay is not optimal - while I am only a research assistant, I don't feel that I am paid enough to cover all of my expenses and living in Boston is  expensive.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: There is nowhere like Boston for research, and nowhere like the Dana-Farber for cancer research. You will have a great opportunity to make a name for yourself, if you're willing to work for it.
cons: You are expected to work very hard - but that is top-level Science, not just Dana-Farber. The specific thing I didn't like about Dana-Farber is that it was not a collegial environment and there was little/no collaboration between laboratories.

pros: Great benefits including excellent time off and 403b matching. Opportunities for growth, wonderful managers, smart and dedicated peers. Decent offices and really great location close to public transportation. But most of all the mission- literally working to cure cancer
cons: Large organization, so it can be more difficult to form relationships with staffers across teams. Sometimes it's tough to know what is going on across the org as well, but everyone is working on communication. The intranet helps with this.

job_title: Human Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: The organization has a very clear mission and takes care of employees through excellent benefits and a caring environment.  The Office for Human Research Studies is a pretty positive environment with an emphasis on teamwork.
cons: Pay is competitive with other non-profits and hospitals but there are limited opportunities for growth within the institution.

pros: Everyone here is highly professional and generally the best in their field. In terms of cancer centers, DFCI is the very best in New England and #4 in the US according to US News and World Report. Management want you to succeed and are usually willing to empower you and let you try new things to succeed.
cons: Not a startup environment. Working for a non profit isn't always the most fun as salaries are slow to grow and bonuses are rare.

job_title: Program Development Associate/Director of Education and Outreach in Brighton, MA
pros: Great people, great mission and an amazing opportunity to work on the front lines of advancements in cancer research.
cons: Minimal support from management, large workload with not much assistance.

pros: Great people, very mission focused, good culture, benefits are a plus. Overall great place to work for and with.
cons: tough career/financial advance internally. once you get hired almost impossible to receive proper financial compensation for promotions/new positions as an internal candidate. Salary is often offered as % increase of current salary as opposed to the budgeted or position pay grade.

review_title: Great to gain healthcare experience and learn a lot too
pros: Really great learning environment - staff very interested in their jobs and their specific disease area. Lots of great seminar/lecture opportunities to really feel a part of the mission and organization. Convenient location too.
cons: Research coordinator positions are really geared towards people who want to work for about 2 years and then leave - lots of burnout happening. Salary is not great for the amount of work expected.

review_title: Great people, management could be better
job_title: Human Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: The other team members were great - young, fun environment, and the work was interesting. Lots of exposure to high power doctors, but little mobility in terms of job opportunities.
cons: The management was not there - there was a lot of gossip and lack of management from the upper tiers. However, overall, this didn't impede much on the work environment.

review_title: A great organization for patients but may not be easy for workers
pros: Great environment in the general vicinity of Longwood medical area.  Some interesting medical talks you can attend if you are interested.  People in general have pride in the work that the institution does.
cons: Average benefit.  Some old-school type of people with closed mind-set.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Reading, MA
pros:
Collegial coworkers.  
Excellent benefits.
Exciting research.
Abundant resources.
DFCI is the best place I have worked as a scientist.  Overall the people are pleasant and ready to help each other because cancer is a tough set of disorders to treat and evaluate.
cons:
Because of the nature of the disease, DFCI tends to be silo-ed--similar to Harvard.  
DFCI uses Partners Healthcare for a number of purposes.  I find Partners to be a dinosaur in terms of modern computing and services.

review_title: A great place to work, but you have to put in the effort and know how to work the academic environment!
pros: There are opportunities to do good work there.  There are plenty of opportunities to see great speakers, hear great talks, etc.
cons: Not a lot of support.  You will spend a lot of time chasing folks down and the support staff tend not to be very helpful.

job_title: New Patient Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: This was my first "professional" job experience after graduating college. I worked in the administrative sector of the hospital, scheduling new patients. The pay was good and I enjoyed learning about the specific diseases that my patients had.
cons: The job itself was incredibly dull. My office was a tiny windowless room that I shared with 2 other people, within a slightly larger room that was shared by 5 others. I often felt like clinicians talked down to my colleagues and I, but hey-- that's administrative jobs, I guess.

pros: Great people, very helpful and kind, fruitful learning environment
cons: Pay was lower than expected, HR is sub-par especially with reimbursements, lab disorganization

review_title: Trying to find another job because I can't abide the culture of the company.
job_title: Senior Research Technician in Boston, MA
pros: Benefits are decent, pay is acceptable, if you don't have too many expenses.
cons: Politically charged atmosphere,  Egotistical people abound.  Lying, back-stabbing, lack of co-operation among departments and co-workers.  Blame game is often played.  Co-workers will set up others to create trouble.  Lack of communication. Disorganized management.

job_title: Principal Research Technician in Boston, MA
pros: I came from a different country to the Dana-Farber and was amazed by the sheer endless amount of resources and research opportunities. At least in my lab there is no technique that we cannot try and even though I am "just" a technician I have my own projects and I'm involved in a lot of great science.  On top of that the benefits are great.
cons: The lab infrastructure is pretty old. The money is definitely rather spent on research than fancy lab benches.

review_title: Great place to pursue your career
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Good science; opportunity to directly listen to and work with world class, renowned scientists; access to resources available in Harvard community
cons: Low salary compared to the expensive living cost in Boston; costly child care further increases the stress; more focus on career development plans can make it even better place to work on..

pros: Very attentive to the needs of their staff. Numerous programs outside of work as well. It's almost like they have clubs for the staff to join. Everyone I worked with was very helpful.
cons: Understaffed when it comes to some departments. You truly need to stay on top of your Dr.s and patients to make sure everything is getting done in a timely manner.

job_title: Social Media Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Great mission that absolutely anyone can get behind. It makes you jump out of bed in the morning. The people working there are also fantastic.
cons: Slow growth opportunities, not a ton of "fun" benefits as it's a cancer research and treatment hospital, the money needs to go to the patients! So if you are looking for all kinds of extras like the ability to go to trade shows, free food or parties this would not be the place for you.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Great patients, smart doctors, excellent academic environment. The doctors are great at recognizing your commitment to the hospital, and there are so many resources available to contribute to a great cause.
cons: Disrespectful and rude managers, little/no opportunity for career growth, very low pay. If you're low-ish on the totem pole be prepared to be completely taken advantage of. Also be prepared for management to disregard your input and opinions. On average, the doctors are very smart and driven but management lacks those attributes and they're who you deal with 99% of your time.

review_title: A lot of work, not enough time
pros: Get to partake in the fight against cancer
cons: Not enough hours in the day to do all the work, which results in extremely poor work/life balance and 10-12 hour work days. Expectations are to do 20 hours of work in an 8 hour day, and any leftover work is expected to be done from home, and failure to complete tasks is dismissed as "poor time management".

review_title: Great place to work and grow
pros: Excellent job prospects, exposure to industry leading professionals, continuously strong growth and expansion, competitive salary offered, great name recognition for increased upward mobility
cons: Transportation to and from the administrative headquarters of Dana-Farber can be extreme if traveling from outside of the Boston Metro area.

review_title: Fellow employees are what make this facility a great place to work.
pros: Dedicated and focused staff are what is the true strength of this company.  Everyone is on the same page and working hard to do anything and everything to assist patients and their families.
cons: There seems to be a pattern of appointing staff into management roles without any proper or prior management experience.  Good employees are being lost to other institutions due to poor management skills.

review_title: Culture of people who really care, from president down
pros: Employees at all levels, clinical and not, really believe in the mission of the Institute and are wholly committed to cancer patients and their families. You can feel really good about supporting this organization.
cons: Non-competitive salaries; also, tendency for people in leadership positions to stay on for years and years - which is not necessarily a bad thing, but can sometimes cause staleness and tunnel vision if left unchecked.

pros: Patient centered & mission driven hospital wide.  Wonderful sense of purpose in all that you do.  Staff is recognized from the top administration and is asked to be involved in hospital wide initiatives.  Overall, great people to work amongst.  Very positive working environment.
cons: Work can be demanding and stressful, as there is a high level of excellence as a standard.

pros: One of the best cancer research institutions in the country due to tremendous faculty, close proximity to great hospitals, and overall environment of excited scientists.
cons: As with all jobs in academia, the pay isn't great for lower level positions. But overall good place to begin career.

review_title: It was not great but was not terrible either
pros: The networking capacity of being a part of HMS!! That really helped. Probarably the only thing that made me stay there for 2 years. Also access to lots of instruments and money from HMS to buy instruments!
cons: Terrible leadership...Absolutely no potential for growth within the same department. Very poor compensation

review_title: Dana Farber Cancer Institute- thumbs up
job_title: Senior Applications Programmer Analyst in Boston, MA
pros: They provide excellent benefits, and the work is rewarding.  I've found it easy to network and learn of higher opportunities.  You feel like a piece of the bigger picture here, no matter your role
cons: Boston Cost of Living presents challenges for proximity to work.  Commutes can be long, MBTA passes can get expensive, and parking nearby costs and arm and a leg

job_title: Clinical Administrative Support Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Job responsibilities are challenging, but really helps improve on your multi-tasking and communication skills; meet many great patients/families/providers
cons: no support from team/manager, lots of "blaming"- no one takes ownership of their mistakes; no appreciation for hard work

pros: The Dana-Farber Cancer institute cares about its patients and physicians. As an employee you get a decent benefits package.
cons: However, postdoctoral fellows doing just research get very little respect from the institute... The most clear example is when you get your own funding through a fellowship or grant; instead of being congratulated for the achievement, you are deprived of all your benefits. Very disappointing. Not to mention the outdated installations...

review_title: This is a great company for those who are just starting their career.
job_title: Regulatory Affairs Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: This company helped me start my career. It gave me a great foundation when I went to obtain entry level regulatory affairs jobs.
cons: This pay is not that great but they do give a sub. commuter pass. My manager was alright, but I learned the most from my peers. Be ready to learn on your own as there is not much instruction.

pros:
Most mission driven organization I have encountered
Great people to work with
Care is very patient focused
Super talented world class faculty. Clinicians are most expert anywhere
cons:
Space is limited
Working across partnerships with other hospitals complicates getting things done
Very little space on main campus. Hard to relate to other site

review_title: limited resources and nickle and dimed
pros: well known name and good reputation
cons:
core facilities and shared equipment is outdated and poorly maintained with major impacts on your ability to work efficiently
they financially penalize you for winning a fellowship
a money making hospital first, research institute distant second

review_title: Solid short term job before moving onto something else
pros: Learned a lot about bench research. Very flexible schedule, incredibly smart colleagues, good benefits. Got to work on some cutting edge science technology. Very reasonable and professional superiors.
cons: Salary isn't great, but if you're just here for a couple years it's reasonable.  Definitely not a job to stay in long term - it's a stopping point before moving on for your post-grad degree.

pros:
- Well-oiled nonprofit with unprecedented access to information about how various development departments and positions should work
- Pays higher than most nonprofits
cons:
- Few opportunities to wear multiple hats
- Cross departmental transitions are mostly lateral
- Lack of diversity; mostly women
- Micro-management

job_title: Novel Cell Therapy Technologist in Boston, MA
pros: You are exposed to a great variety of work, and new clinical trials. The atmosphere is very kind.
cons: Very long training process due to work depending on the ability to find patients. Great exposure, but no vertical growth. For working at a hospital the health insurance leaves a lot to be desired.

review_title: They do amazing work, but not sure how...
pros:
The quality of care and research is unmatched
Great location
Great benefits
cons: Like a hot dog - final product tastes good, but you if you knew the inner workings, you'd be grossed out. Every department is different of course, but my department was lead by a group of power-hungry people who liked to exercise control over we minions who actually perform all of the work.

review_title: Not a bad gig for research.
pros: Notoriety, great equipment. Lots of money to throw around for ideas and reagents etc. A nice place to learn a lot of different techniques.
cons: Pay is far less than industry. Early on this isn't too bad, as it is great for a resume, but if you aren't looking to go to grad school I would recommend going into industry. You'll easily make $10,000-$20,000 more per year.

job_title: Clinical Administrative Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Discounted MBTA passes, discounts on bills including Verizon and ATT etc., some flexibility to work from , paid weekly
cons:
Time off accrues slowly - for new full time employees: 1.83 sick hours per week, 2.8 vacation hours per week, three standard floating holidays
No institution-wide work from home policy, determined at discretion of manager
Many administrative roles work 8.5 hour days

pros:
There are excellent resources available.
Great seminars
Pretty good core facilities
Good name
cons: It is a very dishonest place to be. Lots of had waving and expensive experiments with little substance. A lot of marked favoritism in labs, it is really depressing.

pros: The people there are very helpful and friendly and everyone is working on the same goal. Training is done well and received a lot of hands on experience.
cons: HR doesn't really help, especially in terms of being active on employee issues.

pros: Excellent benefits, opportunities to get small raises, great location in the city
cons: Reporting overtime hours is discouraged, little interaction between research groups, building I work in is wildly outdated and frankly depressing, often difficult to get work orders through bureaucracy, culture of not caring about pay

review_title: Not the best and not the worst.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Boston, MA
pros: Salary is excellent, compared to other hospitals.
cons: Small department with little interaction with outside areas. I barely ever deal with people in other departments. Some micro-management (in my area at least), and feedback is not always given in a positive way.

pros: patients are great, and keep me going! And you get paid weekly which is a pro for me
cons:
The boss is very fickle and doesnt seem like she has a masters degree
 but the management is too micro managed on my floor.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Great access to other learning opportunities and lectures.  Ability to determine next steps re-grad school by meeting with multiple different clinical positions.   Ability to make overtime with the hourly rate during data-base locks.  DFCI historically has had the highest paid CRC positions in the Boston area (compared to BWH, MGH, BI, etc.)
cons: working with pharma companies in clinical research

pros: Benefits, work environment, karma, people
cons: work environment, dealing with Brigham and Women's Hospital Employees

pros: People are smart, really care about the cause, and work hard and since it is a big organization, you often get the financial resources to do projects "the right way"
cons: because it is a non-profit organization, there is a component of doing more with less.  When some projects get fully funded, there is a tight budget and resources are limited for others.

pros: I felt like I had a work life balance for the most part and my supervisor was very supportive.  I didn't have a patient facing job so that probably allowed for more flexibility.
cons: It's big enough that it can sometimes feel like a bureaucracy.

job_title: Lead Research Technician in Boston, MA
pros:
Good benefits: medical and dental, paid vacation, once an invested employee you can obtain your retirement contribution from the company
People: intelligent and friendly work atmosphere, learning from the best 
Perks: tuition reimbursement, healthy incentives, computer reimbursement
Opportunities to excel after: graduate school, better job, better position
cons:
lower end of salary range due to it being non-profit
may be hard to go up in ladder

pros: The reputation of Dana-Farber and Harvard Medical School is a big plus. The research facility and support are superb. The benefit is fine.
cons: There is not enough networking opportunity. Postdoctoral fellows are pretty much isolated in each individual lab and there is few chances to interact with outside world even though that is probably the case for all places.

review_title: One of the best cancer research institutes
pros: Labs always have an eye towards cutting-edge patient care. Great reputation in clinical and basic cancer biology research. Allows fruitful relationships with other labs in the Boston/Cambridge area.
cons: Recent turnover of high level Investigators have depleted quality labs, although many still exist. Improving salary and benefits for postdoctoral fellows but much more work needs to be done.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Great for gaining experience, fast-paced and exciting. People are great to work with, a lot of young people which makes for a fun environment. Lots of opportunity to learn and improve.
cons: Can be extremely stressful, departments tend to take on more than they can handle and there's a lot of regulatory hoops to jump through in a very disorganized system often.

pros:
Talent colleagues and great environment
good collaboration environment
nice facilities,
PI's are mostly serious scientists, talented and hard working
all kinds of grant and fundings
cons:
more career instruction for postdocs
I hope there will be more shuttle bus route and more frequent schedule,
food courts....

review_title: The job at Dana-Farber was a very good experience for the time that i was their
pros: To obtain a position where hard work, reliability and growth opportunities are available and i can use my diverse business skills.
cons: Some of the medical terminology that i had to inter in the system some time was difficult .

pros: Great mentoring and career support from the post doc office. Also have access to most talks and events at HMS. Research is well funded and there is generally easy access to state-of-the-art equipment and facilities.
cons: All researchers are treated as if they interact with patients and have access to patient data creating more hoops to jump through.

pros: Many smart people stick around hoping for a positive change
cons: Really complex reporting structure leads to very small progress overall. Most efficient people leave quickly putting extra burden on an already ineffective system. Usually no incentive for exceptional hires - high personnel turnaround.

pros:
Well respected academic institution
Strong scientific community
Very successful in obtaining grants
State of the art facilities
Opportunity to help others
cons:
Promotions are hard to come by and slow
Salaries are low compared to industry
Not well integrated and some competition between groups

job_title: Research Assistant/Lab Technician in Boston, MA
pros: Good benefits and time off allotments
cons: terrible cutthroat culture which can be a big turnoff

job_title: Bioinformatics Analyst I in Boston, MA
pros: Free ice cream from donations. Salaried and I only work 8 hours a day. Great benefits.
cons: Very hectic. There are always a long list of things to do.

review_title: Unique experience I will always value
pros: Mission oriented patient centric research atmosphere.
cons: As research funding decreased politics have been more of a driving force, and not the same environment that was attractive years ago.

job_title: New Patient Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros:
-Making a difference in individuals life.
-Great benefits.
cons:
-The job can be stressful at times because you have to do many different tasks at once.
-Talking to patients can be difficult since they are going through such a hard time.

review_title: Research jobs highly dependent on which lab you're in
pros:
- Great benefits and workplace perks (e.g. transit discount)
- World-class research centers
cons:
- Zero to little oversight of research labs/centers
- Longwood area is terrible for food
- Low pay for research jobs

job_title: New Patient Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: great benefits, nice bosses, half price t-passes, good vacation time, a good cause, good environment to be in
cons: no room for growth, employees sometimes treated poorly, long break too short, end up working a lot of overtime, hours in flexible

pros:
Everyone committed to the mission 
People very dedicated, giving their best to cure cancer patients and research cures
Striving for excellence
cons:
Partly dysfunctional senior leadership holds Institute back 
Researches often have very tough work conditions, unfair treatments, endless hours

job_title: Senior Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: There are a lot of "intangibles" and you feel very rewarded at the end of the day. Great benefits, supportive teams, and family support
cons: The pay is not the best. You often work long hours for no excess pay and there aren't really any bonuses at the end of the year.

pros: Flexibility with schedule, Great working environment, Positive team members
cons: Lots of employees get recycled through different departments as they aren't performing well rather than get rid of the dead weight. They also recently decreased the health coverage and increased the weekly cost to employees.

pros: Good first job, lots of flexibility for the work schedule. Great vacation time and paid holidays.
cons: Very little room for career advancement and very political atmosphere with multiple different bosses that do not communicate with eachother.

review_title: Dana farber is a great place to work. The patient centered culture is unlike any other
pros: Has a great work culture, you get fairly compensated, plus you get to hear about the latest breakthroughs in cancer
cons: Often very busy. Commuting in can be time consuming and expensive. Its often intimidating being around harvard doctors with MD/PhDs.

review_title: An excellent organization truly devoted to patients and learning.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: At DF I found talented and compassionate colleagues, positive work environment, opportunities within the organization for role changes and continued learning.
cons: At DF no matter the area in which you work, patients are a presence on the campus. Their presence motivates your work day to day.

pros: Some of the brightest mind, unlimited access to high profile seminars, flexible room for learning new things that aren't necessarily applicable to exactly what you are doing
cons: Sometimes a little too focused on academics and work, can get caught up and lose sight of enjoying what you do

job_title: New Patient Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Competitive pay and comprehensive benefits.  Great aesthetic working environment with equally great people.  Loved the work culture and the mission behind all that you do.
cons: While there is a lot of job opportunity to switch positions, there was limited opportunity to move up and have significant bumps to salary.

pros: Exposed to best science on the planet - can learn the world's brightest individuals about the medical topic of your interest.  Your work can really help people.
cons: The commute is generally long.  The area is very expensive.  Only do the job if you have a passion for science.

review_title: good mission, low salaries, no room for growth
job_title: Clinical Research Study Coordinator in Worcester, MA
pros: You will definitely get a lot of experience and will feel like part of something bigger
cons:
Very low salaries and the benefits are not great . Barely any room for growth.
Can be extremely stressful, the institution is definitely under staffed.

pros: Great benefits, lots of intellectual freedom.
cons: Academic salary means you are poor from grad school through the end of your postdoctoral training.

pros: Great place to learn about development from the bottom to the top. Amazing coworkers and environment.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth on certain teams. You really need to advocate for yourself.

job_title: Senior Research Technician in Boston, MA
pros: real sense of motivation here, constant opportunity for growth, management gives feedback and recognition, hires a very diverse work staff
cons: It can be very depressing to see the the number of people who are being treated for cancer, but it can ultimately be a great motivating factor.

pros: I learned a lot of skills here that I will take with me to any route in science. Mentor-ship, engaged research environment, and innovative research techniques is what I valued most while being here.
cons: Responsibilities are high compared to pay but the experience is what I'm valuing the most.

review_title: Great work environment, leadership could improve
job_title: Clinical Research Monitor II in Boston, MA
pros:
-Great benefits
-Open, helpful community
-Well-oiled "machine"
cons: -Leadership doesn't always take into account employees' feelings about overhead decisions, simply because there are so many employees. Often out of touch with employees' needs.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Feels good to work for organization that does such wonderful work for the society.
cons: Poor pay. Gender bias. Poor benefits for postdocs.

review_title: Great Place to Start a Career in Healthcare
job_title: Clinical Scheduling Specialist in Brookline, MA
pros: Working in the ambulatory practice management side of the Institute exposes you to many opportunities to learn from and directly communicate with clinical professionals.
cons: If you are not very good at multi-tasking/organization and handling multiple responsibilities at random on a daily basis

pros: Mission-drive organization with bench-to-bedside research and care. Very plugged into the rest of the healthcare industry of Boston as well as nationally and globally.
cons: Room to further develop clinical research resources in the central Clinical Trials Office, as well as individual career growth opportunities.

pros:
Solving great challenges in research and clinical care
Working with interesting data and opportunity to learn a lot
cons:
Very political
Hard to get anything done
HR onboarding process is a nightmare 
Lack of communication across staff or willingness to hear input from individuals when decision making

pros: Research is great, but you have to try and insulate yourself from the push towards translational medicine encouraged by Benz, Nathan and Nadler - a triumvirate with little care for the collateral damage they cause
cons: Opportunities for advancement as a PhD without an MD are horrific

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: this is a great place to do a PostDoc in the field of Cancer Biology with a lot of possibilities for collaborations
cons: High Pressure environment with low salaries. The interaction between PostDocs could be better, but probably depends on the exact group you are working in

pros: the research being done is cutting edge, there is a good support system for postdocs if you look for it and good health insurance
cons: the cost of living is very high in Boston- living on your own in Boston on a postdoctoral salary is nearly impossible.

pros: Working at Dana Farber as a student researcher has been an amazing experience. Friendly environment, dedication to teaching and a love of science.
cons: HR can be annoying and there is a lot of bureaucracy to get a valid ID as a student

pros: I like the fact that DFCI is continuing to pursue new methods of Cancer Therapy.
cons: Some of the Chiefs and Chairs are not manager however it is all about who you know.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Good institute, lots of resources, good reputation in Cancer research. The postdoctoral association does a good job, organize lots of good activities, training programs. It is good for transaction.
cons: It is not good for stay long unless you are a faculty.

pros: Good exposure to best cancer research in nation, collaborative environment amongst faculty, postdoc association to advocate postdoc rights
cons: post doc salary is really low as compared to living expenditure in Boston,  family and childcare benefits are not good.

review_title: Solid research institution with a strong sense of mission
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Cutting edge work taking on large meaningful problems with implications for clinical care
cons: Compensation is very low and work hours are typically long on the research side.

pros: I like environment and work relationships in my department. I have been with DFCI for over 15 years  and enjoyed my work there.
cons: Lower salaries if compare to industry. No bonuses. Some benefits have been eliminated during hard economy years.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Great benefits (health insurance is okay, 50% off MBTA passes, etc), good company values and atmosphere.
cons: Difficult to obtain ID badges as a collaborator at other institutions within Partners Healthcare system.

review_title: Great place to perform cutting edge research and collaborate with top notch researchers
pros: Great place to perform good research, Develop interpersonal skills.
cons: Careers after a Postdoc are quite stagnant like any other Postdoc.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Good mentorship and excellent research being done here. The focus on understanding and finding a cure for various types of cancer is really good.
cons: There can be a lot more collaborative work that can be done here.

job_title: Senior Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Room for growth, networking in the healthcare industry, good collegial relationships, excellent work perks
cons: Sometimes teams take on more than can be handled by the staff, which leads to errors and burn out. No coherent training program across disease groups.

review_title: Great hospital, great research and people.  Environment can be challenging.
pros: Great research, good resources, coworkers are smart, kind and compassionate.  Helping a lot of patients.
cons: Some facilities need to be updated.  Parking is a nightmare.  We work really hard.

review_title: Inexperienced people and unhealthly working condition
pros: Dana center in other place is nice to work
cons: I worked for two years at MRI facility  In Dana center, The people who manages this facility were inexperienced and no growth potential, Few of my colleagues left after a year. Work like horse in a mouse facility (bio safety leve 2 facility, unhealthy and unsafe condition to work). No research atmosphere. Another headache is a loading dock with construction.

pros: great atmosphere, the entire institute is mission driven.  Salaries are competitive and benefits are generous.
cons: compared to other institutes, I cannot think of one.

review_title: Best benefits I've ever been offered
pros: Benefits are the best compared to all the other hospitals in Boston. Management is stellar! Excellent work life balance
cons: When you talk about what you do, people usually tell you about their relative who had/has cancer

pros: Good opportunities to collaborate, institute has very high reputation
cons: postdoctoral fellows have only minimum benefits (health insurance if at all) and also do not receive much appreciation for their work

pros: enjoyed many coworkers - they made it great to come to work.
cons: management potentials are limited to "those in the know", very busy and high expectations.  not well compensated.

review_title: Great hospital to work out, feels like a community, patients are usually very appreciative of the care they receive.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: good benefits, pay is a better compared to other hospitals, feels like a community.
cons: Can be hard to work with very sick patients

pros: Inspiring, learning opportunities, focus on continuing education (graded tuition reimbursement program), 50% off MBTA passes, community, people
cons: Low pay, few perks, little upward movement for research coordinator/program coordinator staff, no longer a fitness reimbursement, office shortages, high turnover of young staff

job_title: Department Grants Management Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Integrity, mission, the people are great to work with.
cons: Some old systems that long time employees do not want to improve. Unclear career ladder. Some bad apples that don't get held accountable for poor performance.

review_title: Great ecosystem for a Research Associate
pros: Diversity (talented coworkers from around the world), Flexibility to pursue graduate education, and the Benefits are Great!
cons: Salary - Research Assistants/Associates do not make much money, but you do learn a lot.

pros:
Non-profit with a great mission
Great pay and benefits
cons:
Too much focus on growth and making money, especially for a non-profit
